Begini Cara Spyware Israel Membobol WhatsApp
03 Nov 2019, 16:18 by Fitraya Ramadhanny - detikInet


Foto: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images

Jakarta - Pembobolan WhatsApp oleh spyware Israel, belum semua paham duduk perkaranya. Bukan chat-nya yang dibobol, tapi kode jahat masuk ke ponsel lewat WhatsApp.WhatsApp, didukung oleh induknya Facebook, memperkarakan NSO Group ke pengadilan. Perusahaan asal Israel itu dituding bertanggung jawab membuat software mata-mata atau spyware bernama Pegasus ke ponsel pengguna WhatsApp.Serangan Pegasus ini diduga terjadi bulan Mei 2019 kepada 1.400 pengguna WhatsApp di seluruh dunia, memanfaatkan celah keamanan di video call WhatsApp. Setidaknya 100 orang korban adalah para aktivis politik dan HAM, wartawan atau pejabat pemerintahan.Nah, banyak netizen menyangka yang dibobol adalah percakapan WhatsApp. Bukan, bukan itu yang disasar.Time of India seperti dilihat detikcom, Minggu (3/10/2019) memberitakan dokumen tentang Pegasus menyebutkan spyware WhatsApp ini bukan membobol percakapan. Namun ketika dia masuk ke ponsel korban dia mengambil semua data seluler berupa foto, email, nomor kontak, lokasi, arsip, data history browsing, rekaman audio dan kamera."Cuma butuh nomor telepon target untuk meng-install spyware Pegasus. Ia juga bisa mengaktifkan mikrofon dan kamera di ponsel target untuk mendapatkan data," begitu yang terungkap dari data tentang Pegasus.Will Catchart, Head of WhatsApp mengatakan targetnya adalah data penting di ponsel korban. WhatsApp dibobol untuk dijadikan jalan masuk dari kode-kode jahat ke ponsel korban."User akan menerima apa yang kelihatannya video call, tapi ini bukan panggilan normal," kata Will Catchart.(Halaman selanjutnya: Cuma Butuh Nomor Ponsel Korban...) This Is How Spyware Israel Breaks WhatsApp
03 Nov 2019, 16:18 by Fitraya Ramadhanny - detikInet


Photo: Justin Sullivan / Getty Images

Jakarta - Burglary WhatsApp by Israeli spyware, not all people understand the case. It wasn't the chat that was hacked, but the malicious code entered into the cellphone via WhatsApp. WhatsApp, supported by its parent Facebook, took the NSO Group to court. The Israeli company is accused of being responsible for making spy software or spyware called Pegasus to WhatsApp users' cell phones. The Pegasus attack is alleged to have occurred in May 2019 to 1,400 WhatsApp users worldwide, exploiting security holes in WhatsApp video calls. At least 100 of the victims were political and human rights activists, journalists or government officials. Well, many netizens thought that the burglarized was WhatsApp conversation. No, that's not what was targeted. Time of India as seen by AFP on Sunday (3/10/2019) reported a document about Pegasus mentioning WhatsApp spyware is not breaking into the conversation. But when he entered the victim's cellphone he took all the cellular data in the form of photos, e-mails, contact numbers, locations, archives, browsing history data, audio recordings and cameras. "Only need the target phone number to install Pegasus spyware. He can also activate the microphone and camera on the target cell phone to get data, "so revealed from the data about Pegasus. Will Catchart, Head of WhatsApp said the target was important data on the victim's cellphone. WhatsApp was broken into as a way to enter from malicious codes to the victim's cellphone. "Users will receive what looks like a video call, but this is not a normal call," said Will Catchart. (Next page: Just Needs a Victim's Mobile Number ...) ( fay / fyk)
